segment.source: Use Answer Files with Sysprep
segment.target: Use Answer Files with Sysprep

segment.source: Use Answer Files with Sysprep
segment.target: Use Answer Files with Sysprep

segment.source: Use Answer Files with Sysprep
segment.target: Use Answer Files with Sysprep

segment.source: You can use an answer file together with the System Preparation (Sysprep) tool to configure unattended Windows® Setup settings.
segment.target: You can use an answer file together with the System Preparation (Sysprep) tool to configure unattended Windows® Setup settings.

segment.source: This topic describes some considerations and processes for using answer files together with Sysprep.
segment.target: This topic describes some considerations and processes for using answer files together with Sysprep.

segment.source: For more information about Windows components and settings that you can add to an answer file, see the Unattended Windows Setup Reference.
segment.target: For more information about Windows components and settings that you can add to an answer file, see the Unattended Windows Setup Reference.

segment.source: In this topic:
segment.target: In this topic:

segment.target: Running Sysprep an Unlimited Number of Times

segment.source: Running Sysprep an Unlimited Number of Times
segment.target: Running Sysprep an Unlimited Number of Times

segment.source: If you specify a product key, Windows is automatically activated, and you can run the Sysprep command an unlimited number of times.
segment.target: If you specify a product key, Windows is automatically activated, and you can run the Sysprep command an unlimited number of times.

segment.source: To automatically activate Windows by supplying a product key, specify a valid product key in the Microsoft-Windows-Shell-Setup unattend setting during the specialize configuration pass.
segment.target: To automatically activate Windows by supplying a product key, specify a valid product key in the Microsoft-Windows-Shell-Setup unattend setting during the specialize configuration pass.

segment.source: If you don't automatically activate Windows by providing a product key, Windows prompts the end user for a product key.
segment.target: If you don't automatically activate Windows by providing a product key, Windows prompts the end user for a product key.

segment.source: If the end user skips this step during OOBE, Windows reminds the end user to enter a valid product key later.
segment.target: If the end user skips this step during OOBE, Windows reminds the end user to enter a valid product key later.

segment.source: Applying Settings in the generalize, auditSystem, and auditUser Configuration Passes
segment.target: Applying Settings in the generalize, auditSystem, and auditUser Configuration Passes

segment.source: Not all configuration passes run during Windows Setup.
segment.target: Not all configuration passes run during Windows Setup.

segment.source: The generalize, auditSystem, and auditUser configuration passes are available only when you run Sysprep.
segment.target: The generalize, auditSystem, and auditUser configuration passes are available only when you run Sysprep.

segment.source: If you add settings to your answer file in these configuration passes, you must run Sysprep to apply these settings as follows:
segment.target: If you add settings to your answer file in these configuration passes, you must run Sysprep to apply these settings as follows:

segment.source: To apply the settings in the auditSystem and auditUser configuration passes, you must boot in audit mode by using the Sysprep/audit command.
segment.target: To apply the settings in the auditSystem and auditUser configuration passes, you must boot in audit mode by using the Sysprep/audit command.

segment.source: To apply the settings in the generalize configuration pass, you must use the Sysprep/generalize command.
segment.target: To apply the settings in the generalize configuration pass, you must use the Sysprep/generalize command.

segment.source: The generalize configuration pass removes the system-specific settings so that you can deploy the same image on multiple computers.
segment.target: The generalize configuration pass removes the system-specific settings so that you can deploy the same image on multiple computers.

segment.source: For more information, see How Configuration Passes Work.
segment.target: For more information, see How Configuration Passes Work.

segment.source: Caching Answer Files to the Computer
segment.target: Caching Answer Files to the Computer

segment.source: If you install Windows by using an answer file, that answer file is cached to the system.
segment.target: If you install Windows by using an answer file, that answer file is cached to the system.

segment.source: When later configuration passes run, the computer applies settings in that answer file to the system.
segment.target: When later configuration passes run, the computer applies settings in that answer file to the system.

segment.source: Because this answer file is cached, when you run the Sysprep command, the system applies settings in the cached answer file.
segment.target: Because this answer file is cached, when you run the Sysprep command, the system applies settings in the cached answer file.

segment.source: If you use the settings in a different answer file, you can specify a separate Unattend.xml file by using the Sysprep /unattend:filename option.
segment.target: If you use the settings in a different answer file, you can specify a separate Unattend.xml file by using the Sysprep /unattend:filename option.

segment.source: For more information, see Sysprep Command-Line Options.
segment.target: For more information, see Sysprep Command-Line Options.

segment.source: For more information about how to use an implicit answer-file search, seeWindows Setup Automation Overview.
segment.target: For more information about how to use an implicit answer-file search, seeWindows Setup Automation Overview.

segment.source: Persisting Plug and Play Device Drivers During the generalize Configuration Pass
segment.target: Persisting Plug and Play Device Drivers During the generalize Configuration Pass

segment.source: You can persist device drivers when you run the Sysprep command together with the /generalize option.
segment.target: You can persist device drivers when you run the Sysprep command together with the /generalize option.

segment.source: To do this, specify the setting in the Microsoft-Windows-PnPSysprep component.
segment.target: To do this, specify the setting in the Microsoft-Windows-PnPSysprep component.

segment.source: During the specialize configuration pass, Plug and Play scans the computer for devices, and then installs device drivers for the detected devices.
segment.target: During the specialize configuration pass, Plug and Play scans the computer for devices, and then installs device drivers for the detected devices.

segment.source: By default, the computer removes these device drivers from the system when you generalize the system.
segment.target: By default, the computer removes these device drivers from the system when you generalize the system.

segment.source: If you set the Microsoft-Windows-PnPSysprep setting to true in an answer file, Sysprep doesn't remove the detected device drivers.
segment.target: If you set the Microsoft-Windows-PnPSysprep setting to true in an answer file, Sysprep doesn't remove the detected device drivers.

segment.source: Displaying RunSynchronous Actions in an Answer File
segment.target: Displaying RunSynchronous Actions in an Answer File

segment.source: In audit mode, you can view the status for Microsoft-Windows-Deployment commands that run during the auditUser configuration pass.
segment.target: In audit mode, you can view the status for Microsoft-Windows-Deployment commands that run during the auditUser configuration pass.

segment.source: The AuditUI window displays the status for commands and provides these:
segment.target: The AuditUI window displays the status for commands and provides these:

segment.source: Visual progress to indicate that an installation is continuing and not suspended.
segment.target: Visual progress to indicate that an installation is continuing and not suspended.

segment.source: Visual indication of when and where failures occur.
segment.target: Visual indication of when and where failures occur.

segment.source: This provides a quick diagnosis if the command doesn't create log files.
segment.target: This provides a quick diagnosis if the command doesn't create log files.

segment.source: If the answer file contains Microsoft-Windows-Deployment commands in the auditUser configuration pass, a list of the commands appears in the AuditUI window.
segment.target: If the answer file contains Microsoft-Windows-Deployment commands in the auditUser configuration pass, a list of the commands appears in the AuditUI window.

segment.source: The commands appear in the order that the Microsoft-Windows-Deployment setting specifies.
segment.target: The commands appear in the order that the Microsoft-Windows-Deployment setting specifies.

segment.source: Each list item in the user interface is the string from one of these:
segment.target: Each list item in the user interface is the string from one of these:

segment.source: Microsoft-Windows-Deployment (if present)
segment.target: Microsoft-Windows-Deployment (if present)

segment.source: Microsoft-Windows-Deployment
segment.target: Microsoft-Windows-Deployment

segment.source: Sysprep processes all commands in order.
segment.target: Sysprep processes all commands in order.

segment.source: If the command succeeds, its related list item receives a green check-mark annotation.
segment.target: If the command succeeds, its related list item receives a green check-mark annotation.

segment.source: If the command fails, its related list item receives a red X annotation.
segment.target: If the command fails, its related list item receives a red X annotation.

segment.source: If the command requests a reboot, the AuditUI window appears after the boot, but only unprocessed list items appear.
segment.target: If the command requests a reboot, the AuditUI window appears after the boot, but only unprocessed list items appear.

segment.source: Previously processed items no longer appear in the AuditUI window.
segment.target: Previously processed items no longer appear in the AuditUI window.

segment.source: If the list of items in the AuditUI window exceeds the height of the display, the list is truncated to the display and doesn't scroll.
segment.target: If the list of items in the AuditUI window exceeds the height of the display, the list is truncated to the display and doesn't scroll.

segment.source: As a result, you may not be able to see some items.
segment.target: As a result, you may not be able to see some items.

segment.source: Windows Setup interprets the return codes as status values in the AuditUI window.
segment.target: Windows Setup interprets the return codes as status values in the AuditUI window.

segment.source: A zero value indicates a success.
segment.target: A zero value indicates a success.

segment.source: A nonzero value indicates a failure.
segment.target: A nonzero value indicates a failure.

segment.source: The return value of the command might affect the behavior of Windows Setup, depending on the value of the Microsoft-Windows-DeploymentWillReboot setting.
segment.target: The return value of the command might affect the behavior of Windows Setup, depending on the value of the Microsoft-Windows-DeploymentWillReboot setting.

segment.source: If the command is set to Always:
segment.target: If the command is set to Always:

segment.source: If the command returns 0, its related list item receives a green check-mark annotation.
segment.target: If the command returns 0, its related list item receives a green check-mark annotation.

segment.source: A reboot immediately occurs.
segment.target: A reboot immediately occurs.

segment.source: If the command returns a nonzero number, its related list item receives a red X annotation.
segment.target: If the command returns a nonzero number, its related list item receives a red X annotation.

segment.source: A reboot immediately occurs.
segment.target: A reboot immediately occurs.

segment.source: A nonzero return value isn't treated as a fatal error when is set to either Always or Never.
segment.target: A nonzero return value isn't treated as a fatal error when is set to either Always or Never.

segment.source: If the command is set to Never:
segment.target: If the command is set to Never:

segment.source: If the command returns 0, its related list item receives a green check-mark annotation.
segment.target: If the command returns 0, its related list item receives a green check-mark annotation.

segment.source: If the command returns a nonzero number, its related list item receives a red X annotation.
segment.target: If the command returns a nonzero number, its related list item receives a red X annotation.

segment.source: A nonzero return value isn't treated as a fatal error when is set to either Always or Never.
segment.target: A nonzero return value isn't treated as a fatal error when is set to either Always or Never.

segment.source: If the command is set to OnRequest:
segment.target: If the command is set to OnRequest:

segment.source: If the command returns 0, its related list item receives a green check-mark annotation.
segment.target: If the command returns 0, its related list item receives a green check-mark annotation.

segment.source: If the command returns 1, its related list item receives a green check-mark annotation.
segment.target: If the command returns 1, its related list item receives a green check-mark annotation.

segment.source: A reboot immediately occurs.
segment.target: A reboot immediately occurs.

segment.source: If the command returns 2, its related list item temporarily receives a green check-mark annotation.
segment.target: If the command returns 2, its related list item temporarily receives a green check-mark annotation.

segment.source: A reboot immediately occurs.
segment.target: A reboot immediately occurs.

segment.source: After the reboot, the related list item appears again in the AuditUI window without annotation because the command is still in process.
segment.target: After the reboot, the related list item appears again in the AuditUI window without annotation because the command is still in process.

segment.source: If the command returns other values, a fatal error occurs and a blocking dialog box appears.
segment.target: If the command returns other values, a fatal error occurs and a blocking dialog box appears.

segment.source: If the Errorhandler.cmd file is present, no dialog box appears.
segment.target: If the Errorhandler.cmd file is present, no dialog box appears.

segment.source: For more information about the Errorhandler.cmd file, see Add a Custom Script to Windows Setup.
segment.target: For more information about the Errorhandler.cmd file, see Add a Custom Script to Windows Setup.
